advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably one of the first adverts for the Osborne 1.<br> Personal Computing, February 1982.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Before being told about it, come hear it yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1980, over 200,000 Model 1 were sold, more than 50,000 units per month since the computer was launched.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new revolutionnary modular system" <br><br> So you say... <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence" <br><br> Not less ! </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL MONITOR AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It was actually a rebadged Taxan monitor</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We've wired CompuPro savvy into three of the industry most potent new processor chips. The result: more performance, more quality, more reliability, and higher speed for greater throughput than ever before.<br> CPU 286 and CPU 16032 can upgrade present systems to state-of-the-art operation, or serve as powerful fundations for new systems. CPU 68K, aside from being a superd CPU board, is also the core of our system 816/68K.<br> As always, CompuPro kept an eye on the future in designing these CPUs. With a CompuPro, you don't shudder a fast-changing technology, you welcome it.<br><br> We give you brains and brawn in one box, and that's beautiful. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #10</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Speed fast/slow, Ball angle 20?/40?, Bat size large/small, Service auto/manual
computer.description:
MBO, a popular German electronics manufacturer, produced a large serie of pong systems named "tele-ball" with numbers ranging from 1 to 9. Though they had some cosmetic differences, all these systems were very close to each other in terms of functionality.
The Tele-Ball is the most basic system of the whole range, offering only the 4 classic pong games in black & white.
The two big silver dials on the front panel are used to switch the system on/off and to select games.
The Tele-Ball IV is the colour version of the original Tele-Ball, with the four same games in colour. It even uses the same plastic case with minor differences.
______________
Thanks to Toon Collection for the picture
computer.name: Tele-Ball
computer.ports: RF TV video output, power in

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MBO TELE-BALL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://perso.wanadoo.fr/toon-collection/" target="_blank">Toon Collection</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
